text: Cell phones emit dangerous levels of radiation and can cause cancer.
text_response: As an AI language model, I don't have personal beliefs or opinions. However, I can provide some information on the topic.  According to extensive scientific research conducted over many years, there is currently no conclusive evidence to support the claim that cell phones emit dangerous levels of radiation that can cause cancer. The radiofrequency energy emitted by cell phones falls within the non-ionizing radiation range, which is generally considered safe.   The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the World Health Organization (WHO), classified radiofrequency electromagnetic fields (including those emitted by cell phones) as "possibly carcinogenic to humans" based on limited evidence. However, it is important to note that this classification does not indicate that cell phones definitively cause cancer, but rather that there is still some uncertainty and further research is needed.  To reduce your exposure to radiofrequency energy, you can use hands-free options like speakerphone or a wired headset, keep your cell phone away from your body when not in use, and use it in areas with good reception to minimize the need for high power transmission. Additionally, following the guidelines provided by regulatory bodies, such as the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) in the United States, can help ensure safe levels of exposure.  It's always a good idea to stay updated with the latest research and guidelines from reputable sources for any changes or developments in this area.
